Celebrate Chicago and its Black History

Welcome!

With its first non-Indigenous permanent settler being the Black trader Jean Baptiste Point du Sable, Chicago is a city with a rich and long history of Black culture and accomplishments. Use this site to learn more about Black Chicago’s people and culture as we celebrate the last days of Black History Month.

Explore Chicago’s Black History and Culture During Black History Month

Chicago Cultural Center: The Chicago Cultural Center’s current in-person exhibit Art and Race Matters: The Career of Robert Colescott explores Black creative Robert Colescott’s paintings, which comment on deeply-rooted racial and social inequalities in the United States. There is also a virtual discussion and commentary on his work for those who cannot see it in-person

Chicago Public Library

Chicago Public Library: The Chicago Public Library is hosting free in-person and virtual screenings and events in honor of Black History Month. The next events are an in-person screening of Black-directed and produced Stomp The Yard and a virtual event, Let’s Talk About It: The Black Community and the Stigma of Mental Health. (https://chipublib.bibliocommons.com/events/).

Museum of Science + Industry Chicago

Museum of Science + Industry Chicago: The Museum of Science + Industry Chicago’s annual Black Creativity Juried Art Exhibition is a multi-media art exhibit that showcases African American art. In addition to featuring work from African American youth artists aged between 14 and 17, the museum and exhibit encourage Black youth to explore science, technology, engineering, art, and medicine (STEAM) through their Black Creativity Program (https://www.msichicago.org/explore/whats-here/exhibits/black-creativity-juried-art-exhibition/).

The DuSable Museum of African American History

The DuSable Museum of African American History: Founded by Black artist/educator/writer/activist Margaret Taylor Burroughs in 1961, the DuSable Museum is a beacon of celebrating Black history, art, and culture in Chicago. You can explore their latest exhibit The March, an immersive and virtual that explores the history of the 1963 March on Washington for Jobs
